column14: This book is a strange, intriguing book, although this is about violence, it is also about the good and evil. This book was a great book although it did not gain my interest too fast, once i got far into the book it got interesting. The beginning of this book was one of the most boring sections of a book i have read. I read two books over the summer, this being one of them. The other book seemed boring, but turned out to be good, this only took my interest by the beginning of the middle. A Clock Orange is great book, it gains my interest about this troubling boy named Alex, who is sentenced to fourteen years in prison. I do not relate to this book one bit, but I still do enjoy this very much. The real question this book got me to think is; is being good, actually good, if it is not by choice than is being bad not by choice either? That is the way I see the book and how it effects me.

column13: violent society without giving any indication about how it got to be like that. Teenagers roam in packs committing horrific acts
column14: I found ACO to be a bit too artsy for my tastes.  Burgess creates this dystopic, violent society without giving any indication about how it got to be like that.  Teenagers roam in packs committing horrific acts of violence as if this is a perfectly natural human impulse.  His offerings concerning the interplay of morality and choice are interesting.  The MC's conversion into a "solid citizen" simply because he becomes an adult is a bit of a stretch.
Good book, but could not stand the jargon.
Scarey.  A classic

Whoo Hoo, I finally managed to get though this and understand the slang. For anyone who wants to read it but isn't sure I say go for it. The hardest part of reading this amazing novel was the nadsat slang used in the book. Gosh!  What a way to start a book, having to look up  almost every other sentence to figure out what exactly this crazy teen was saying. Once you get deep into the novel and get used to all that slang, the book is an easy read and amazing at making a good argument. Should criminals have a say in how they're treated, and should the government take away their right to choose? Violence is all this crazy teen has in mind as he both rapes and beats innocent people. He becomes the subject of some sort of experiment in where he is forced to feel sick while witnessing violent films of very real situations. I was left both feeling bad for this kid and wanting him to stay a "good boy" forever. The ending is brilliant and it left me wanting the next chapter of Alex's life. If you haven't read this you are missing out.

column13: and ultimately sad. It offers a first-person perspective of a violent ...
column14: This book is very dark, thought-provoking, and ultimately sad. It offers a first-person perspective of a violent criminal, but the steps taken to neutralize the threat he poses are questionable. The author does a great job getting us to actually feel empathy towards the character, even though by the standards of most people he is a horrible human being. The question is left to the readers, does free will encompass the freedom within one's mind? This book will forever hold a place on my Favorites shelf.

column13: Worth reading, especially if you like the movie
column14:
I had been putting off reading this book for decades, but I finally got around to it because I wanted to see how it compared to the film. I was not disappointed.

While there are small differences between the book and movie, the story is essentially the same. The book adds more context and details, which make it worth a reading if you're a fan of the movie. Among those inclusions: An explanation of where the book's title comes from. But the movie at the same time left very little out of Anthony Burgess' original story. Of course, the book itself is barely 200 pages, so the film doesn't have to slice and dice the story to cram it in, a la "The Lord of the Rings" or "Harry Potter." The added details, the changes, and Alex's additional first-person musings make the original novel worth a read.

As other reviewers have noted, the book adds the final chapter that was missing from the movie and the American version of the book. I have mixed feelings about the "redemption" chapter, but I don't believe it makes the book any worse.

The hardest part of reading the book is the Nadsat. My copy of "Clockwork Orange", the Penguin Books version, had a Nadsat glossary, which was handy — even though it slowed down reading considerably. Most of the Nadsat words' meanings can be guessed or just glossed over, but if you want to know what's really being said, Google "Nadsat glossary" and have the reference handy.

column13: Terrible writing style by the author.
column14:
Having seen the movie I wanted to read the book. Unfortunately this book is so poorly written that I stopped in frustration a little ways past part 3 (chapter 23ish). Every sentence has 'like' in it, so much so that I couldn't even concentrate on the story being told. "I tried to like read, but like couldn't like concentrate because the like author sounded as if he was an like uneducated like fool."
On top of that the author repeats many words for no apparent reason other than to fatten up the word count. Instead of saying 'and the camera went flash' he would say 'and the camera went flash flash flash' and he uses this toddler form of description dozens of times through what parts I could bear.
My biggest gripe is that the author thinks it's cute to make up long winded slang for simple words (again, probably just to fatten up the book). 'Viddy' is slang for 'see', 'slooshy' is 'hear' and so on. He makes up a compacted word for nearly everything and it's up to the reader to figure out what he means.
If the author would have left out the issues I've detailed here this book would have probably only been 100 or less pages. My advise, skip the headache this book gives and just watch the movie or better yet just read a better book by a better author. Have you read Don Quixote?

column13: He loved it. Gave him the DVD as well
column14: Purchased this as a gift for my friend.  He loved it.  Gave him the DVD as well.

Of all the early 1960s novels made famous by later movie adaptations (The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie and One Flew Over the Cuckoos's Nest come to mind), A Clockwork Orange is perhaps the one most able to stand on its own. Irrespective of Stanley Kubrick's unforgettable cinematic version (and Malcolm McDowell's star turn as Alex), Anthony Burgess' achievement in this book cannot be overstated.    A dystopian nightmare of frightening plausibility, it explores the nature of free will through the experiences of its protagonist Alex, a juvenile delinquent who is maneuvered into undergoing aversion therapy that in effect forces him to be \\"good.\\" A number of characters opine that such conditioning severs a man from choice, eliminating his humanity. \\"Does God want goodness or the choice of goodness?\\" asks one. \\"Is a man who choses the bad perhaps in some way better than a man who has the good imposed upon him?\\" One need not believe in a God to understand the philosophical stakes implied by those questions.    Burgess does a great job of stacking the deck to make the point. Alex is undeniably despicable. By age 15 (his age at the start of the book) he has committed numerous acts of \\"ultra-violence\\" that has left at least two people dead, participated in a brutal gang-rape, molested a pair of 10-year-old girls and perpetrated numerous acts of theft and gratuitous vandalism that have terrorized his community. He is clearly a cancer on society and society has a reasonable rationale for taking him out of circulation through incarceration (or perhaps, at the extreme, execution). But does it have a right to remove his free will? That is the uncomfortable question Burgess asks.    Clockwork Orange is the second dystopian novel Burgess published in 1962. The other, The Wanting Seed, lacks Clockwork Orange's tight structure, consistent theme and anything close to Alex as a dramatic center, something made even more unforgettable by Alex' first-person narration in an idiosyncratic Slavic/English polyglot slang. The only two book-length first-person in-character narrations I can compare it to in 20th century English language literature for sheer end-to-end brilliance are Holden Caulfield in J.D. Salinger's Catcher in the Rye and Humbert Humbert in Vladimir Nabokov's Lolita.    The book also exposes the generational rift emerging in British society in the late 50s and early 60s. If one watches some of the \\"kitchen sink dramas\\" being made around that same time by directors like Tony Richardson and John Schlesinger (The Loneliness of the Long Distance Runner, also dating from 1962, is an excellent example), one can see the utter befuddlement of the older generations, still clinging to king-and-country traditions, when faced with the aggressive, cynical attitudes of the young, particularly the young of the lower classes. Gangs like Alex's \\"droogs\\" had their real-life counterparts in the Teddy Boys and the early Mods.    Clockwork Orange can also be seen as an indictment of the kind of secular, scientifically planned societies then in vogue, which Burgess exposes as breeding cynicism by weakening traditional checks on amoral behavior such as religion and parental authority, setting the stage for authoritarianism (a cultural/political cycle that he explores more overtly in The Wanting Seed).    A Clockwork Orange is a bravura achievement as a philosophical meditation and also a hell of an entertaining read. What more can one ask?

column13: Burgess is able to brilliantly maneuver past these obstacles by implementing the Nadsat language ...
column14:
Anthony Burgess’ novella, A Clockwork Orange, attempts to expose the corruption and weaknesses of government and the manipulation it can bring upon society. By creating a futuristic city that is ruled by a totalitarian state, Burgess is able to reveal his beliefs on Man’s free will and choice that distinguishes Him from lower animals and machines.
At the very start of the book, the reader is introduced to the main protagonist Alex, who seems to lack any of the usual traits that the main character would often have. We find Alex the perpetrator of numerous crimes of theft, rape, and harassment throughout the first part. And yet the reader is supposed to believe that Alex is the protagonist, or hero, of this dystopian society. However, Burgess is able to brilliantly maneuver past these obstacles by implementing the Nadsat language used often by Alex and his droogs. The Nadsat is an apt usage of diction in which Alex’s brutal crimes have been censored (i.e. rape is ultra-violence, gang violence is twenty-to-one) and the reader is almost brainwashed into believing that these acts aren’t as terrible as they actually seem.
Burgess’ extensive use of symbols and motifs are incredibly effective in his purpose of the novel. The most evident recurring symbol would be Christ and how Alex is the “savior” of his society. Burgess connects these two figures in a multitude of forms. In the final 3 days of Jesus’life, Christ is killed, buried, and resurrected. In the 3 chapters that Your Humble Narrator describes for us, Alex is captured, imprisoned, and returned to normal. The crucification of Jesus is analogous to Alex jumping out of the window of his apartment. Both acts were a result of the cruel government in which they were ruled by, and both actions labeled them as martyr figures. The idea of Ludovico’s technique, or conditioning is a powerful theme of the entire novella. Man’s free will and choice of whether to be good or evil are aptly explained by Burgess. After Alex is put under this treatment, he is not only forced to do good, but cannot commit the most basic of human abilities such as self-defense, and emotional expression. Burgess makes a strong note of this lack of free will when Alex is beaten by Officers Billy and Dim, and Alex’s lack of musical expression.
Although Burgess is able to aptly reveal his beliefs on free will and government structure, he fails to effectively reveal other themes in the novella. Alex obviously undergoes an epiphany/catharsis event in which he believes he has outgrown the childish actions of crime and evil. However, he never denounces the practice of his inherent destruction as a child, but claims that it will pursue in a continuous cycle among the youth. Along with the notion of cyclic torment, the current totalitarian regime’s fate of reelection was never mentioned and has remained a mystery. In fact, the reader may possibly assume that the Minister of the Interior was voted in again because he made amends with Alex in the 20th chapter, and F. Alexander is restrained due to his epiphany that Alex raped and killed his wife.
Ironically, Burgess never intended for A Clockwork Orange to be his greatest or most renowned works of his literary career. In fact, he denounces this novella as flawed, but he accepts the unexpected glory it has received. It is plain to see why the book has received an enormity of recognition. The text contains a unique writing style and twisted plot that invokes inner thinking and realization of the world around us. Yet there are noticeable faults in plot, theme, and author’s intention. So it can best be described as, simply, a happy accident.d by Burgess. Although Burgess is able to aptly reveal his beliefs on free will and government structure, he fails to effectively reveal other themes in the novella. Ironically, Burgess never intended for A Clockwork Orange to be his greatest or most renowned works of his literary career. In fact, he denounces this novella as flawed, but he accepts the unexpected glory it has received. It is plain to see why the book has received an enormity of recognition. When I first started reading it I found it difficult because of the constant slang in the book, to get used to this I used a dictionary online meant for words in the book. This was very helpful at the beginning but eventually you pick up on it and get used to it. This book was very interesting, it was a mix of many things and could be considered multiple genres. It is sometimes dark, funny, sad, and even scary. This is one of the reasons it is constantly interesting to read. It is not a book for everyone however I must say. It goes over very touchy subjects and includes violence and worse. This is all used to portray the story and the message so personally I think it works out. I would recommend this book to somebody if they were looking for a novel that is different and are prepared to read some pretty crazy stuff.

A Clockwork Orange is one of the most brilliant books that I have had the pleasure of reading. The book is so nicely written, and the little invented language that the characters talk in is so fun to try to decipher. However, this book might not be good for a lot of people. There is an invented language in here, and some readers might struggle to figure out what some of those words actually mean. There is also so much violence in this book that some people may not be comfortable reading about. Overall, this book is one of the best I have ever read because of the excitement of a story from an anti-hero's point of view.

The opening essay was enlightening. I intend to look into other works by Burgess since he values those books more than A Clockwork Orange. I completely understand where he is coming from. It seems like many artists are cursed by one particular work that simply gains more fame than any other.

I think the 21st Chapter is essential just as the author intended. I understand that it seems like a copout to some but if that is the intention of the writer, so be it. At the very least, we should not be deprived of an entire chapter that leads to our subsequent understanding of the book.

Overall, I like the book although I am not as high on it as others are. The Nadsat really turned me away at first. I recommend reading the book with audio assistance to get the terminology down. It's easier to picture the dialogue that way. Just YouTube the audio and something will come up.

A Clockwork Orange by Anthony Burgess was a very intriguing and riveting novel that kept me reading to the very end, despite my reservations of the protagonist's Alex's slang. The story sucks you into a world in abject fear of criminals at dark, leaving a very resentful population of young and old people. To remedy this the government creates this new but crude technique that sends the protagonist into a downward spiral of misery and pain and makes you wonder how far one can and should go to "cure" the criminal mind. For these reasons I gave it four out of five stars. The only downside I found with the book was that the slang utilized by our beloved narrator almost prevented me from moving further on in the story. It took me a while to fully understand it, like what in the world a gulliver was, but I managed to adapt. Not only did it almost ruin the story for me, I might have missed important context in the beginning due to the extensiveness and complexity of the slang. All in all, I would recommend this to those that are interested in reading a great classic with a unique take on the good vs evil theme. If you truly enjoy and get into the book, you will find yourself speaking nadsat, Alex's slang, without even knowing. Overall, the story was good, very deep and revealing and I recommend you find an edition with the real last chapter as well for a truly whole experience.

A Clockwork Orange is a different unlike any other. Anthony Burgess has a very unique writing that you won't find anywhere else.  The book is separated into three parts that take you through the three major sections of the main character's (Alex) life. Alex is a teenage boy who has a taste for violence. Although Alex is a teenage miscreant, Burgess manages to have you sympathizing for Alex after every punishment.  For instance, after a failed heist, Alex finds himself in some trouble with both the law and his friends. Even though Alex had brought it upon himself, you still feel emphatic. Once you understand the foreign slang Burgess uses, you will love the book all the way through just as I did. Highly Recommended.

column13: Good read once you figure out what is happening.
column14: A Clockwork Orange by Anthony Burgess is a novel that is well written but hard to comprehend what is happening due to the “language barrier” that Burgess created with the nadsat speak that goes on throughout a majority of the novel. It is broken up into 3 different parts, all with unsettling actions, consequences, and questions that will make you wonder what kind of world they are living in. Part 1 consists of introducing the protagonist, Alex, he is a young man who fears nothing whilst around his gang, consisting of three other boys his age. There weekends consist of drinking drug laced milk, beating people on the streets, breaking into homes and raping unwary citizens, and getting in brawls with other gangs just like them. All behold to Alex though, he makes his gang very unhappy which results in them setting him up, which lands him 14 years in prison. The first part of the book is the most difficult to understand, for it uses the largest amount of nadsat throughout the entire novel I believe. Once you get a hold of what they are saying, it will be easier to understand what is happening. In the second part Alex deals with the real life consequences of hard prison time. He has to deal with other prisoners, constantly beating him, and trying to rape him. With guards not even willing to help, he is on his own for his first stretch of prison, fending for himself from other prisoners and corrupt guards. Once the prison offers him a deal to cut back on his time in prison, he accepts it almost immediately, even though he has no ideas the consequences it will have on him later on his life, changing him forever. Over the course of his time in prison, Burgess really shows character development for Alex, how he becomes a changed man vividly by depicting what goes through his head the whole time he is getting the treatment. The rest of the novel shows Alex’ life slowly spiraling back into his previous life, being bad, until he finally thinks about one thing that makes him change his thoughts a bit. This is a good novel to read due to how it goes about solving issues dealing with yourself, or a man vs. man deal. Alex doesn’t necessarily choose to be bad, he just naturally is bad, and not much can change that. You get the sense that the whole time he has a moral struggle of whether or not it is good to be bad or good? If he chooses one of those how will it impact his future, that’s what is comes down to for Alex, thinking about the future and what it will bring to him. You don’t discover the main theme until later on in the novel which deals with the humanistic nature and how bad people will always be that bad person until they can find something that they look forward to, other than doing the things that make them bad. Again, once you get past the “language barrier”, you unveil a novel that explores ideas that are shunned upon in our society today.
Came in a custom made package with drawings everywhere. Shows that there was a lot of care taken when the book was being packaged. I was not expecting that at all, but was very pleasantly surprised.
This book was very interesting but also very strange. They speak in a gibberish language in the book that can be kind of hard to decipher sometimes. I still enjoyed it though.

"Clockwork Orange" is a classic.  It is required reading in many schools.  The first time I read it was in a college class studying satire.  Back then (70's)  I viewed it as a mixed genre of horror and science fiction.  I recently reread the book and this time came away thinking that Anthony Burgess is somewhat of a modern day prophet.  "Clockwork Orange" is a dark fable about good vs. evil.  The book asks what is human freedom really worth? I suggest you read it or re-read it.  Guaranteed, this book will get you thinking.

Rape, beating the crap out of others, and breaking into houses as well as bribing people - all on the first 10 pages. I was a literature major in college and with that degree I think I deserve a small right to judge books for my own opinion. The only somewhat reason to call this book literature is the doublespeak lingo.

This book is the product of a diseased mind or, more likely, of someone desperately wanting literary attention.  He got his attention only because literary standards have been so degraded in the last fifty years.  Someone who throws nonsense language about as he does here, not to mention endlessly cascading gratuitous violence does so only because he lacks genuine talent. Consequently, he compromised and took the cheap route.
"I do not know of any other writer who has done as much with language as Mr. Burgess has done here — the fact that this is also a very funny book may pass unnoticed." - William S. Burroughs
Love the fact it is the original print! In very awesome condition and shows it's age in some discoloration of 30+ years but a wonderful classic must have collectors books.

column13: Wind Him Up And Watch Him Go!...
column14: Like many, I had seen Kubrick's film version long before settling down to read Burgess' book. Because of this, I considered A CLOCKWORK ORANGE to be a black comedic masterpiece of sociopathic glee / anti-social behavior, mixed w/ a political message about state control. Now, after reading the book, w/ the restored twenty first chapter, my view has changed a bit. Burgess had intended to present Alex as a purely id-driven human being w/ free will. The horrific crimes he commits, along w/ his droogs, are done out of a choice to commit them, and not due to any outside forces. Alex is happiest when stealing, hurting, and / or raping people, pure and simple. Along comes the government w/ its "cure" for those like little Alex (he's only a kid after all) which involves mind-altering, chemically induced "goodness" in place of "evil". Burgess' central questions seem to be: Are we still human if we have no choice? and Is "goodness" really of any value if it has to be induced? While state control is evident, it is secondary to the idea of losing one's humanity in order to be a decent citizen. Chapter twenty one shows us a completely different person in Alex, when set against the marauding, insanely violent boy of the previous chapters. Burgess leaves room for growth, evolution, and the wisdom of age. Actually, he leaves us w/ the possibility of hope...
This was actually written by Anthony Burgess. Stanley Kubrick directed the movie. Please change this for accuracy. Derp d' durh.
This is a pretty crazy book with a language all it's own.  It tells a good story of a possible future society.

column13: The classic book of an even greater classic movie!
column14:
EVERYONE has at least probably heard of A Clockwork Orange, be it the book or the movie. I watched the movie first and found out about the book later, and read the book much later. The version of the book that had the original or controversial ending is totally ruined by the ending, this is the version to go for, especially because this version has in the back of the book a dictionary of the slang words used in the book. I much prefer the movie all day every day, but this is an excellent book no less.

A Clockwork Orange (Without Controversial Ending) **** out of *****

Violent Content: 4/10 - Some Violent Content and Fighting, Beatings, Cruelty.
Descriptions of Sexual Content: 3/10 - Suggested.

My rating for the version of this book that has the other ending is **1/2 out of *****, it totally ruins the book and clears up way to much and explains way to much making everything that was great about this book the opposite of even being OK.
The book was in marvelous condition! It also had an extra chapter added to to it! Thank you for everything!

Burgess is a linguistic & observational genius.  The ultra violent world he creates is as real as any fictional world with parallels in experience can be, with its own standards & language.  His anti-hero is supremely confidant & therefore short-sighted.  The revenge society (including his own) takes is grotesque; & the measures instigated by social engineering backfire as the opportunist re-asserts himself to take advantage of blunders by the social elite.  Richly underlying this storyline is Burgess' satirical humor & intelligence.  I have read this novel before & had to buy it again as another reader 'stole' it from me, by failing to return it!
I watched the movie in college and thought about it for days. Later I read the book and I thought about it for weeks.
Loved everything about it. The vocabulary is actually very easy to get use to too. The only thing I didn't like about it was the extra chapter at the end.

column13: A real horrorshow book, my droogies!
column14:
Man, oh man. Why did I wait this long to read this?

This is one of the most brilliant books I have ever read. Ingenious in the way it is written, executed, and created. Anthony Burgess created a fascinating, gruesome world, in which he sucks you right in leaving you feeling sick to your stomach but intrigued nonetheless. He created an entirely new language, confusing you and entertaining you all at the same time. I was at first very confused and put off with the lingo used, and it was hard deciphering all the words and making sense of it, but soon enough you get the hang of it and you start to enjoy reading and decoding it. Like the book cover said, it will take you no more than fifteen pages to get used to the language.

Our honorable narrator, fifteen year old, Alex is an ultraviolent hooligan who goes around with his droogies (gang) causing havoc around town every night. Beating people up (no matter the age and gender), thieving, raping, and ultimately, killing. Violence is in his blood, he can't help himself.

But Alex does have one weakness, and that is classical music. Mozart, Beethoven, Bach, and the like transport him to a completely different world, demonstrating a much softer side to this violent criminal.

When Alex is set up and betrayed by his droogies and is caught by the millicents (a.k.a police) and is locked up in prison, he thinks his life is over. Two years in however, he attempts to stay on his best behaviour with the hope he can leave sooner than intended - that is until he is set up once again, this time by his droogies in prison, and is blamed for the death of one of the prisoners. He then agrees to undergo an experimental treatment called the Ludovico Technique, which is a form of aversion therapy in which Alex receives an injection that makes him feel sick while watching graphically violent films, eventually conditioning him to suffer crippling bouts of nausea at the mere thought of violence. As an unintended consequence, the soundtrack to one of the films, Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, renders Alex unable to listen to his beloved classical music.

The prison chaplain is against this treatment accusing the government of stripping people of choices, and what's the point of good and evil if you can't make the choice?

Upon releasing Alex, we then experience the aftermath of this treatment and how it affects his life outside of prison. As a result, we witness Alex unable to defend himself as he is abused and beaten up until he can't take it anymore and attempts to end his life.

It is fascinating experiencing this journey with Alex from violence to non-violence, from control to helplessness. There is so much controversy around this story, people analyzing and judging and deciding what should have happened to Alex and whether he deserved to be let go, or whether having him undergo that treatment and become a "good" person makes up for all the crimes he has committed in the past.

I won't sit here and analyze, but I found it interesting that when put in any given situation, anyone is capable of such violence. Such as the elderly people in the library, who held Alex against his will, and beat him to a pulp to avenge the old scholar he assaulted earlier in the book.

This is a great dystopian novel, and now that I've finally read the book, I look forward to watching Stanley Kubrick's controversial adaptation.

A Clockwork Orange is a must-read. I thought it would take me a long time to get through, but it only took me a couple of days. Easy, quick and entertaining, this book will make you laugh, cringe, gasp, curse and most importantly, it will get you thinking and put a smile on your litso.intended consequence, the soundtrack to one of the films, Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, renders Alex unable to listen to his beloved classical music.

column13: a masterpiece re: the vagaries of art
column14:
the movie is devastating, complex and very thought provoking...but one scene in particular, shades the manner I feel about art, and
probably will for all time. Kubrick informs us...alex is in the ludovico studio, strapped to the chair, eyes forcibly open, & injected with
nausea inducing serum. and the rape & violence parades across the screen. alex is aware of the nausea. right then, hitler, y'sh
at Nuremberg appears and schiller's ode to joy from alex's beloved 9th becomes part of this tableau as "muzak", completing the
incredible image. Beethoven and hitler, y'sh, both hail from Germany which has to say something about ethnic lassitude in terms of
the moral nature of man. and alex has his own agenda in which Ludwig van plays so devastating a role. at ludovico, he must confront
it in horror...just masterful

column13: O my brothers, remember sometimes thy little Alex that was. Amen. And all that cal.
column14:
This book is one of a disturbing type. I would not necessarily recommend it for young readers because of some of the content. For people who are older this book is disturbing, thought provoking and brilliant all at the same time.

The story is told by the central character Alex who is violent and bad just because that is who he is. Him and his gang go around creating havoc until Alex is mutinied by them and left to be arrested. The story talks in a a brutal invented slang that at first can make the book hard to understand, but adds to his and his friends different social pathology. Through all the different writing techniques that arise some very important questions and brought up: to what extent do people go to make everyone "good?"

In a very interesting way the author shows a duality between the government and the young people who rebel. It is shown in a dark twisted way the freedom that the boys want and at a point have. The police are trying to reign in this horrid behavior and are wanting to fix the ones who are caught in violent heinous acts.

A Clockwork Orange was in the end a good read. It kept me interested in what was going on and really had an effect on some of my thoughts regarding freedom and how a person is. It will appeal to people for many different reasons. It will effect people in completely different ways; but it will effect them.

257 Customer Review #806, very positive 19/11/2014
A Clockwork Orange (Stanley Kubrick, 1971, 137')

Directed, produced and written by Stanley Kubrick
Based on A Clockwork Orange by Anthony Burgess
Starring Malcolm McDowell, Patrick Magee, Adrienne Corri, Miriam Karlin,
Music by Walter Carlos, Cinematography by John Alcott, Editing by Bill Butler.
Artwork of the now-iconic poster by Philip Castle, layout by designer Bill Gold.

Anthony Burgess' 1962 novella A Clockwork Orange employs disturbing, violent images to comment on psychiatry, youth gangs, and other social, political, and economic subjects in a dystopian future Britain. The film's central moral question (as in many of Burgess' books) is the definition of "goodness" and whether it makes sense to use aversion therapy to stop immoral behaviour. A critical target is the behaviourism or "behavioural psychology" propounded by psychologists John B Watson and B F Skinner. Burgess disapproved of behaviourism, calling Skinner's book Beyond Freedom and Dignity (1971) "one of the most dangerous books ever written".

Kubrick fell by chance on the novel. "I was excited by everything about it: The plot, the ideas, the characters, and, of course, the language. The story functions, of course, on several levels: Political, sociological, philosophical, and, what's most important, on a dreamlike psychological-symbolic level". Kubrick wrote a screenplay faithful to the novel, saying, "I think whatever Burgess had to say about the story was said in the book, but I did invent a few useful narrative ideas and reshape some of the scenes". Kubrick based the script on the shortened US edition of the book, which missed the final chapter (restored in 1986). The film's Ludovico technique is widely perceived, however, as a parody of aversion therapy more than of classical or operant conditioning.

Burgess reports in his autobiography You've Had Your Time (1990) that he and Kubrick at first enjoyed a good relationship, each holding similar philosophical and political views and each very interested in literature, cinema, music, and Napoleon Bonaparte. Burgess's 1974 novel Napoleon Symphony was dedicated to Kubrick. Their relationship soured when Kubrick left Burgess to defend the film from accusations of glorifying violence. A lapsed Catholic, Burgess tried many times to explain the Christian moral points of the story to outraged Christian organizations and to defend it against newspaper accusations that it supported fascist dogma. He also went to receive awards given to Kubrick on his behalf.

Stanley Kubrick, writing in Saturday Review, described the film as: "...A social satire dealing with the question of whether behavioural psychology and psychological conditioning are dangerous new weapons for a totalitarian government to use to impose vast controls on its citizens and turn them into little more than robots." Similarly, on the film production's call sheet Kubrick wrote: "It is a story of the dubious redemption of a teenage delinquent by condition-reflex therapy. It is, at the same time, a running lecture on free-will." A Clockwork Orange was photographed mostly on location in metropolitan London and within quick access of Kubrick's then home in Barnett Lane, Elstree.

The above text is a very shortened excerpt of four slightly edited paragraphs of the original Wikipedia text. I have concentrated on Burgess and Kubrick, who were two extraordinary people, and on the main format. The full review runs over many pages, and also discusses some of the useless, but at the time (I was around when the film first came out) extremely heated lengthy debate about censorship. I found it very indicative at the time that governments, which, through the police, are the executors of censorship everywhere, were very touchy on the subject and mostly unhappy that “pornography” (of which there is hardly any by today’s standards) was their only handle for intervention: They would all have preferred to ban the movie altogether for subversiveness – like Eastern Europe would have done/did, but that was out for the free and liberal West…
